sa12.21:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove in Śrāvastī.
sa12.21:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa12.21:2.2: “If a monk observes precepts and cultivates virtue, conscience, and modesty, he’ll achieve the true teaching.
sa12.21:2.3: Seeing this person will often be fruitful.
sa12.21:2.4: If he’s also heard, followed in memory, and followed into homelessness, it will often bring virtue.
sa12.21:2.5: It’s even more so to associate with, honor, and serve him.
sa12.21:2.7: Associating with and serving such a person, a monk can hear the profound and subtle Dharma from time to time.
sa12.21:2.8: After hearing the profound Dharma, he’ll achieve the two ways of being correct: correctness of body and correctness of mind.
sa12.21:2.9: He’ll skillfully cultivate the awakening factor of concentration.
sa12.21:2.10: After cultivating it, he’ll cultivate its fulfillment …
sa12.21:2.11: he’ll cultivate the fulfillment of the awakening factor of equanimity.”
sa12.21:3.1: After the Buddha taught this sutra, the monks who heard what he taught rejoiced and handed it down.
